title: Einar Texas Ljungberg
text:
Einar "Texas" Ljungberg (26 August 1880 - 6 December 1974) was a <a href="Sweden">Swedish</a> <a href="Socialism">Socialist</a> politician.
Einar Ljunberg joined the <a href="Social%20Democracy">Social Democratic</a> movement in <a href="Gothenburg">Gothenburg</a> in the early 1900s, and was active in the ranks of the <a href="Swedish%20Social%20Democratic%20Party">Swedish Social Democratic Party</a>. In 1909, he served almost one year in jail for <a href="treason">treason</a>, after having criticized the <a href="Monarch%20of%20Sweden">Swedish Monarchy</a> and arguing for its replacement with a <a href="Democracy">democratic</a> <a href="republic">republic</a>.
After his release from prison, Ljungberg traveled to America and toured the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> speaking about socialism to <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>n immigrants there. Upon his return to Sweden, he was given the nickname ""<a href="Texas">Texas</a>"" by his <a href="comrade">comrade</a>s.
Einar "Texas" Ljungberg was part of the <a href="Far%20left">left</a>, pro-<a href="Bolshevik">Bolshevik</a> opposition within the Swedish Social Democratic Party, and, after the split of 1917, he joined the newly founded <a href="V%C3%A4nsterpartiet">Swedish Communist Party</a>. He took part in the third Congress of the <a href="Comintern">Comintern</a> (in <a href="Moscow">Moscow</a>, 1921).
After the rise of <a href="Stalinism">Stalinism</a> in the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, he left the Communist Party and returned to the Social Democratic Party.
